data.sampled: No, 5 pounds of manganese is not heavier than 20 pounds of hydrogen. It is essential to convert the elements into their respective masses of their most common isotopes. Manganese (Mn) has an atomic mass of 54.94 and hydrogen (H2) has an atomic mass of approximately 2 grams per mole, which is equivalent to 0.0361 pounds. Therefore, 5 pounds of manganese is roughly 0.7165 pounds, while 20 pounds of hydrogen is approximately 0.4450 pounds. Since 0.7165 pounds is greater than 0.4450 pounds, 5 pounds of manganese would be heavier than 20 pounds of hydrogen.
